results.title: JGLING/Whistling
results.brief_description:
JGLING:
Close up low-angle shots of a juggler in action bring the viewer right inside the circle of flying objects.

This short video captures the almost hypnotic appeal of watching a skilled juggler at work; the visual rhythms, the ever changing patterns, and the pleasurable anticipation of collapse.

THE FIRST INTERNATIONAL WHISTLING CONTEST:
The First International Whistling Contest was held in Carson, Nevada, 1978. This documentary captures the sweet sounds and light-hearted atmosphere of the day. The participating whistlers not only perform a range of tunes in a variety of styles, from the classical to the comic, but also share details of their technique.
From the man who whistles with a bunch of cigars and cutlery in his mouth, to the woman who claims she could have had a career at Disney animation because, “You can’t hardly get a bird to whistle when you want to”, these characters and their talents are showcased in a style that is immediate, fresh and breezy.

Director Skip Blumberg was a founding member of Videofreex, one of the many alternative media collectives (such as Raindance, Global Village, Ant Farm and TVTV) that blossomed in the 1970s in response to the development of relatively cheap and portable video systems such as Sony’s Portapak. This new technology was embraced both by artists interested in its aesthetic properties and activists inspired by its potential as a tool of political and social change, enabling individuals access to mass communication via cable television and community media networks.

results.title: Max Harris
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
As a founder of the “Angry Penguins”, Max Harris was at the forefront of the modernist movement in Australian poetry. He recalls the ferment in the artistic community as writers, painters and musicians struggled to find an authentic Australian voice and the uproar surrounding the Ern Malley controversy. Harris remembers his friendship with Sydney Nolan and the journey they made together which inspired the artist to paint his Ned Kelly series. A poet, author, publisher and social commentator, Max Harris gives a unique overview of a vital period in Australian cultural history.

results.title: Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II
results.brief_description: The second series of Archival Film Programs on Australian writers contains minimally-edited interviews with writers at home and at ease. We listen to their anecdotes, personal philosophies and are given a rare insight into their influences and motivations. These archival interviews are unique slices of social history and provide a picture of early Australia.

results.title: Dorothy Green
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Poet, journalist, author and academic, Dorothy Green speaks of her early childhood in England. She recalls the atmosphere of Sydney University in the 1930’s and her early success as a poet which led to a career in journalism. Green worked as a teacher and university lecturer in 1972, a grant enabled her to devote herself to writing. Green reads and discusses several of her poems and speaks of her spiritual beliefs and attitudes towards death. Interviewed by James Murdoch.

results.title: Gold fever
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, George Cass, TV Ed Productions and Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description: They came to get rich quickly and escape poverty in their homelands, but what they found was not always wealth. This program looks at life on the goldfields and discusses some of the problems that the diggers encountered. Sovereign Hill at Ballarat is featured.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeff Spencer, George Cass, TV Ed Productions and Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch

results.title: Street XRays
results.brief_description:
Drawing on the NSW Police Department’s photographic archive, Street X-Rays interprets approximately sixty crime scenes from the 1950s, to evoke the power of the continuing life of the past in our ordinary, everyday places.

The police images are placed beside contemporary footage recorded in the same location, from the same camera position. Each screen holds two moments in time, two disparate attempts to interrogate a location. Texts from police records and the artist’s enigmatic narrative prompts punctuate this essentially visual dialogue. The effects of time linger in each scene and across the entire imaginative space of this half-historical/half-mythical city that is evoked in the installation space.

I’ve tried to conjure a place that’s haunted by persistent little pulses of history. I hope viewers feel as if they’ve wandered into a vaguely familiar ‘otherworld’ that’s being buffeted by a kind of ‘spirit weather’ - Ross Gibson.

Taken from PROOF exhibition 2004

results.title: lifeSigns: eco-system of signs and symbols
results.material_description: video, interactive software, computers, monitors, projection, PVC stands, colour and audio
results.brief_description: An interactive digital networked work where participants play selected emotions as game identities in any manner they choose, the results seen in a fluid projection onto a mounted floor screen between the game terminals in the form of a dynamic and fluctuating virtual realm. Through playing the game, then, the participant contributes to building an ecosystem of sentiments at play and in conflict with one another. The ‘life signs’ chosen by participants are generated as three dimensional icons that construct an evolving virtual language of symbols, sounds and behaviours in interaction with the audiences’ collective participation. The floor projection represents the fluctuating results of the networked game, while an immersive soundscape simultaneously responds to the ever-changing game narrative.The more participants, the greater the intensity of image and sound. The process of the audiences use of and play with sentiments and emotions thus becomes the foundation in constant flux for the visual and aural world that the audience engages with in the installation.

results.title: Burnout 2001
results.brief_description: Burnout 2001 is an interactive game which allows users to use a catalogue of authentic burnout movements to create various markings on the screen. A variety of vehicle’s available each having a particular speciality to their burnout.

results.title: Persuaders
results.creator_credit: David Chesworth, Sonia Leber and Wax Sound Media
results.brief_description:
The installation is composed from ‘fragments’ of video and audio captured in real time from short bursts of activity to longer passages of action or inaction.

Each monitor contains an individual person who has been videotaped while barracking for a particular sport. Each person is presented in close-up, with the eyeline straight to camera, staring directly at the viewer. The sound of each person is also in ‘close-up’, transmitted through a number of loudspeakers in the space. With apparent proximity, we can hear great detail in the breath and voice.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Chesworth, Sonia Leber and Wax Sound Media
